title: How does redundancy work in English? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, one example is that “He works” indicates twice that it is singular—both the pronoun and the -s ending cue that. “They were there last week” tells us that the subject is plural in both the pronoun and the verb, and it tells us that it’s past in both the verb and the time marker. This is what I think is meant by redundancy in linguistics. It’s a feature, not a bug. In an oral presentation, a good speaker builds redundancy in, in order to help us form a mental map of what they are saying. They tell you that there are 3 reasons, they tell you the 3 reasons, they tell you that these 3 reasons lead to this conclusion. I don’t think this is unique to English, though. Redundancy (linguistics) - Wikipedia
The same way it does in any language—i.e., saying something twice you only need to say once, or using repetitious phrasing when a single, short term would do the same trick.
